item.title: Today I Learned: The Rule of 72
item.description: I came over a .pdf on linkedin, which I’m unfortunately unable to find again, containing some lessons of investing from Benjamin Graham’s mentor1. One of them was the rule of 72. The rule of 72 is used to find out how long it takes to double your investment given an annual return rate:

item.title: Mammals
item.description: Travel back 100,000 years and the planet was rich with a wide array of wild mammals. Mammoths roamed across North America; lions across Europe; 200-kilogram wombats in Australasia; and the ground sloth lounged around South America.
item.author: (by Hannah Ritchie and Max Roser)

item.title: Wild mammals have declined by 85% since the rise of humans, but there is a possible future where they flourish
item.description: Wild mammal biomass has declined by 85% since the rise of humans. But we can turn things around by reducing the amount of land we use for agriculture.
item.author: (by Hannah Ritchie)

item.title: #lang lua
item.description: I’m currently working on a macOS app that’s built with Racket and allows the user to write small scripts to process and filter some data. While Racket is definitely my preferred language and I could easily use it for these scripts, my target audience for this app would probably appreciate a more familiar language. I decided to use Lua. So, last weekend I was faced with a choice1 between writing FFI bindings for Lua or implementing a #lang in Racket.
item.author: (Bogdan Popa)

item.title: My journey to using Directus
item.description: Directus is an open-source data platform that allows you to build a backend in hours instead of weeks. I wanted to expand on how I started using it and my experience so far. Spoiler: it's been amazing ✨
item.author: (Ruben Gommers)

item.title: Why Substack will win over everybody
item.description: Blogs have been the avenues that amateurs flock to when they crave lighter opinions. There are no serious incentives for bloggers to write a 3000-word post that is deeply researched. Even though the masses don’t yearn for these deep posts, humanity as a whole needs them. These are the posts that document human civilization’s behaviour as a whole or write well balanced opinionated posts. And to write these posts is no mean feat. You can only find these breeds in New York Times, New Yorker or Washington Post and they attracted all these talents by providing a platform(already established audience) and lucrative career options. But the underlying thing of these entities is that they had a distribution moat. Not anymore.

item.title: Tracing HTTP Requests with tcpflow · Anantha Kumaran
item.description: PagerDuty went off very early in the morning, and our hero cursed his bad luck and received the phone call. He made PagerDuty repeat the message twice, but couldn’t understand the message. He pressed the number to acknowledge the incident. He opened the MacBook and found the slack message from the PagerDuty bot more informative. He clicked the link and it took him to a Grafana Dashboard.
